Author: davidw
Content:
It's not trivially easy though. Part of growing a market is also having connections in that market. For instance, the i18n of reddit would have been trivially easy in terms of programming (I think, at least - there aren't too many strings there). This has been around for a while:

http://it.reddit.com

But they've been absolutely beaten by a localized clone:

http://oknotizie.alice.it/

In part, because the guy behind it, Salvatore "antirez" (on this site, too) Sanfilippo already had a popular Delicious clone, and was able to get significant traffic from that from the outset, in addition to being reasonably well known amongst Italian hackers on his own.

Author: axod
Content:
Sounds like a great idea to me. Anything that cuts down the repetitive questions is great.

For instance in ##javascript, half the questions posed end with the answer "Use a closure".

These are public channels anyway, archiving them seems fine to me. I'm surprised google hasn't got in on this yet.
